name: Imperial Purple
6_mix: 25% Pthalo Blue (GS), 25% Ultramarine Blue, 50% Quinacrinone Rose
Additional Information: The PV19 pigment in Imperial Purple may cause neutralization (greying) of the color if mixed with blues containing green undertones.

name: Aussie Red Gold
6_mix: Equal mix Pyroll Scarlett, New Gamboge, Hansa Yellow Light. Add additional Pyroll to increase red tone
3_mix: 10% Phtalo Blue, 45% Quinacridone Rose, 45% Hansa Yellow Light. Add additional Quinacridone to increase red tone
Additional Information: This is a three pigment color and may lose transparency with additional mixes. Very close in tone to Quinacridone Gold, but non-granulating

name: Buff Titanium
6_mix: Very Dilute 50% New Gamboge, 25% Pthalo Blue (GS), 25% Quinacridone Rose
3_mix: Very Dilute 10% Hansa Yellow Light, 45% Quinacridone Rose, 45% Pthalo Blue (GS).
Additional Information: Due to presence of the white pigment, this shade will cause any watercolor mixed with it to loose translucency.

name: Bismuth Vanadate Yellow
Additional Information: This is a more opaque pigment and may cause other colors to lose their translucency. The pure yellow pigment will allow it to mix nicely with most greens.

name: Hansa Yellow Light
Additional Information: This is considered the "Perfect Yellow". The purity of the pigment will allow it to mix with most colors while avoiding grey undertones.

name: Cadmium Yellow Light Hue
Additional Information: A replacement for the more toxic original Cadmium Yellows, this contains three yellow pigments and my result in unexpected colors when mixed with other multi-pigment colors

name: Cadmium Yellow Medium Hue
3_mix: Dilute 75% Hansa Yellow Light, 25% Quinacridone Rose
Additional Information: A replacement for the more toxic original Cadmium Yellows, this contains three yellow pigments and my result in unexpected colors when mixed with other multi-pigment colors

name: Aureolin (Cobalt Yellow)
Additional Information: Very similar to Hansa Yellow Light, but tends to be more fugitive.

name: Hansa Yellow Medium
3_mix: Hansa Yellow Light with very little Quinacridone Rose.
Additional Information: Very similar to Hansa Yellow Light, but slightly warmer.

name: Lemon Yellow
Additional Information: Slightly more green then Hansa Yellow Light. Will make bright greens when mixed with a cooler blue and neutralized greens with a warmer blue.

name: Indian Yellow
3_mix: Hansa Yellow Light with very little Quinacridone Rose.
Additional Information: A orangish yellow that will make more olive tones with blues due to its red undertone. Very similar to New Gamboge.

name: Naples Yellow
Additional Information: This orange yellow is mixed with a white undertone. This will make the color appear chalky when dry and may dull other mixtures.

name: New Gamboge
Additional Information: New Gamboge is an excellent choice for a warm yellow. Due to its more redish hue, it will make duller greens when mixed with blues. Mixing it with Ultramarine Blue can yeild a wonderful neutral

name: Pyrrol Orange
6_mix: Equal mix Quinacridone Rose, Pyrrol Scarlett, Hansa Yellow Light.
Additional Information: A wonderful bright redish orange. Slighty more pink then red when dilute. Excellent addition to flesh tones.

name: Perinone Orange
Additional Information: Similar to Pyrrol Orange, but more red then pink when dilute.

name: Transparent Pyrrol Orange
Additional Information: Very intense red-orange. Mixes with greens and blues for a range of earthy browns and shadow greys.

name: Organic Vermilion
Additional Information: Very intense red that has orange undertones. Not as light-fast as Pyroll Scarlett.

name: Quinacridone Coral
6_mix: Equal mix Quinacridone Rose, New Gamboge, Hansa Yellow Light.
Additional Information: Intense red-orange with slightly more pink then red undertones. Will make excellent oranges with Hansa Yellow Light or Lemon Yellow.

name: Pyrrol Scarlet
Additional Information: Clear bright red. Will make redish browns or muted purples when mixed with blues.

name: Cadmium Red Medium Hue
Additional Information: True red, but hidden yellow Y53 pigment will prevent this red from mixing clean purples.

name: Pyrrol Red
Additional Information: True red and will make cleaner mixes then Cadmium Red Hues due to its single pigment.

name: Quinacridone Red
3_mix: Quinacridone Rose with a small amount of Hansa Yellow Light
Additional Information: Made with the same pigment as Quinacridone Rose, but more red leaning. Will not mix to make bright oranges due to the presence of the violet pigment.

name: Alizarin Crimson
3_mix: Quinacridone Rose with a small amount of Hansa Yellow Light
Additional Information: Very nice red that can mix a wide range of hues with Hansa Yellow Light and French Ultramarine. However, it is a fugitive color and will fade more quickly then other options.

name: Permanent Alizarin Crimson
3_mix: Quinacridone Rose with a small amount of Hansa Yellow Light
Additional Information: Designed as a less fugitive Alizarin Crimson. However, the presence of a violet pigment, PV 19, may cause it to mix neutralized, rather than bright colors,  with yellows or blues with green hues.

name: Opera Pink
Additional Information: Very bright pink, but extremly fugitive. Use with extreme caution for any painting that will be displayed.

name: Quinacridone Pink
Additional Information: Mixed with warm blues for rich purple. A very dilue mixture with a red orage will create rich flesh tones.

name: Quinacridone Rose
Additional Information: Mixed with warm blues for rich purple. A very dilue mixture with a red orage will create rich flesh tones.

name: Quinacridone Magenta
Additional Information: Slighly more purple than Quinacridone Rose. Looks wonderful in florals contrasted with greens.

name: Quinacridone Violet
Additional Information: Similar to Quinacridone Rose and Magenta, but leans more to the violet. Makes wonderful, clear purples with Ultramarine Blue and deep neutrals with Pthalo Green.

name: Cobalt Violet
Additional Information: Highly granulating, light pink to violet color. Due to its non-staining qualities, it will lift easily and not reccomended for glazing

name: Rose of Ultramarine
Additional Information: This highly granulating color is nearly impossible to get in a secondary mixture. The paint seperates into blue and violet granules while drying. Excellent effect, but difficult to control in mixes.

name: Quinacridone Purple
6_mix: 50% Quinacridone Rose, 25% Pthalo Blue (GS), 25% Ultramarine Blue
Additional Information: Very rich red purple. Excellent Transparency.

name: Ultramarine Violet
6_mix: Very dilute 50% Quinacridone Rose, 50% Ultramarine Blue
3_mix: Very dilute 80% Quinacridone Rose, 20% Pthalo Blue (GS)
Additional Information: Made by baking the same pigment that makes Ultramarine Blue. This is a highly granulating light purple.

name: Carbazole Violet
6_mix: 50% Quinacridone Rose, 25% Pthalo Blue (GS), 25% Ultramarine Blue
Additional Information: Highly granulating color that is difficult to mix. Granulates into violet and almost black granules. Difficult to control in mixes.

name: Cobalt Teal Blue
6_mix: Very Dilute equal mix of Hansa Yellow Light, Ultramarine Blue and Pthalo Blue (GS)
3_mix: Very dilute 80% Pthalo Blue (GS), 20% Hansa Yellow Light
Additional Information: Mix with pink or magenta for neutral purples or green-golds for bright greens.

name: Moonglow
Additional Information: This is a specialty pigment from Daniel Smith that granulates into three different colors, a blue, red and violet. However, the presence of a green pigment(PG 18) will make this very difficult to mix and should be used as an accent.

name: Shadow Violet
3_mix: 75% Pthalo Blue, 20% Quinacridone Rose, 10% Hansa Yellow( or enough to neutralize)
Additional Information: A specialty neutral that has both warm violet and orange undertones. The presence of both Green and Orange pigments makes this difficult to intoduce into mixtures.

name: Indigo
6_mix: 50% Pyrrol Scarlett, 25% Pthalo Blue(GS), 25% Ultramarine Blue
3_mix: 20% Quinacridone Rose, 40% Pthalo Blue (GS), 40% Hansa Yellow Light
Additional Information: Dark bluish neutral, the presence of the black pigment may make this color look flat in mixes. Instead, mix using the paintings primary colors.

name: Indanthrone Blue
6_mix: Equal mix of Pthalo Blue (GS), Quinacridone Rose, Ultramarine Blue. Add additional Ultramarine Blue if a more blue shade is needed or Quinacridone Rose for more purple
Additional Information: Deep purple blue. Black pigment may deaden the color in mixtures, but can be wonderful as a primary blue with Anthraquinoid Red, Indian Yellow for a moody palette

name: Ultramarine Blue
3_mix: Pthalo Blue (GS), hint of Quinacridone may make it more purple, but could neutralize.
Additional Information: Deep redish blue. A wonderful choice for a primary blue in many triads. Very powerful on its own, can be neutralized with small amounts of yellow to orange.

name: French Ultramarine
3_mix: Pthalo Blue (GS), hint of Quinacridone may make it more purple, but could neutralize.
Additional Information: Daniel Smith claims this is warmer then Ultramarine Blue, but it is made with the same pigments and displays the same mixing qualities.

name: Cobalt Blue
3_mix: Dilute Pthalo Blue (GS), hint of Quinacridone may make it more purple, but could neutralize.
Additional Information: Similar in tone to a dilute Ultramarine Blue. Useful if Ultramarine is too strong, but otherwise is a weaker chroma. Can be used as a primary blue in triads.

name: Phthalo Blue Green Shade
Additional Information: Highly transparent and single pigment. Mix with Hansa Yellow Light for bright greens and New Gamboge for neutral greens to greys. Makes a wonderful warm neutral when mixed with Pyrrol Scarlett

name: Phthalo Blue Red Shade
6_mix: Equal mix of Pthalo Blue (GS), Pyrrol Scarlett, Ultramarine Blue
3_mix: Pthalo Blue (GS) with a hint of Quinacridone Roset to neutralize
Additional Information: Slightly neutralized version of Pthalo Blue (GS). Perfect for shadows, expecially when mixed with Quinacridone Rose

name: Prussian Blue
6_mix: Pthalo Blue (GS), can be slightly shifted with Hansa Yellow Light to make more green
3_mix: Pthalo Blue (GS), can be slightly shifted with Hansa Yellow Light to make more green
Additional Information: Almost interchangeable with Pthalo Blue (GS), but slightly more green. This means it will make more neutralized greens with warm yellows and greys with warm reds.

name: Cerulean Blue
6_mix: Dilute Ultramarine Blue with a touch of Pthalo Blue (GS)
Additional Information: Very light pure blue. Hightly granulating and not a very strong color. If looking for a primary blue, look to Ultramarine Blue instead.

name: Cerulean Blue Chromium
6_mix: Dilute equal mix of Ultramarine Blue, Pthalo Blue (GS), Hansa Yellow Light
Additional Information: Very light blue with a greeish hue. Due to the green tone a variety of natural mossy tones can be achived mixing with a warm yellow or gold

name: Manganese Blue Hue
6_mix: Dilute equal mix of Ultramarine Blue, Pthalo Blue (GS), Hansa Yellow Light
Additional Information: A replacement for the more toxic Mangaese blue, this specialty pigment granulates into blues and greens. Overall it gives a warm turquoise tone, but is difficult to control in mixes.

name: Phthalo Turquoise
Additional Information: Rich green blue that appears green at full strength, but fades to a blue when diluted. The green pigment means it will produce neutralized purples when mixed with reds and greys when mixed with warm yellows.

name: Ultramarine Turquoise
Additional Information: Almost identicle to Pthalo Turquoise, but highly granulating.

name: Lunar Blue
6_mix: Very dilute equal mix of Pthalo Blue (GS), Pyrrol Scarlett, Ultramarine Blue
3_mix: 60% Pthalo Blue (GS), 30% Hansa Yellow Light, 10% Quinacridone Rose
Additional Information: Specialty blend from Daniel Smith. This is a neutral grey which will granulate into black and blue pigments. Nearly impossible to replicate in a mix. The highly granulating nature makes it unstable in mixtures and should be used as an accent.

name: Viridian
6_mix: Dilute 75% Pthalo Blue (GS) 25% Hansa Yellow Light
3_mix: Dilute 75% Pthalo Blue (GS) 25% Hansa Yellow Light
Additional Information: Used primarly as a mixing tool to neutralize Quinacridones in portraits and florals

name: Phthalo Green Blue Shade
Additional Information: Can be neutralized with reds or yellows. Contains a black pigment, which may make it appear flat.

name: Cascade Green
3_mix: 50% Pthalo Blue(GS), 50% Hansa Yellow Light, touch of Quinacridone Rose to neutralize.
Additional Information: A brown pigment helps neutralize this deep green that can be used as a shadow in florals. The green shade makes it will create neutralized greens with warm yellows and greys with warm reds.

name: Phthalo Green Yellow Shade
Additional Information: Very bright pure green. Can be mixed with warm yellows for bright spring greens.

name: Hooker’s Green
Additional Information: A bright warm green, the presence of an orange pigment will cause it to produce neutralized greens if mixed with a blue with a redish hue. Will make a wonderful neutralized sea color when mixed with Ultramarine blue. The presence of so many pigments in this paint causes a wide variety of shades from different manufacturers and can cause problems when mixing with other multi-pigment colors.

name: Sap Green
Additional Information: A strong orange pigment warms this green and makes it perfect for natural foliage. Mix with Ultramarine Blue for deep forest shadows or Quinacridones for autumn tones.

name: Deep Sap Green
Additional Information: More blue then regular Sap Green and leaning to black. Mixes will with pure orange for a redish brown.

name: Perylene Green
Additional Information: Neutralized black green. Perfect for moody palettes. Can be made by mixing Crimson with Pthalo Green

name: Undersea Green
Additional Information: A mix of Ultramarine Blue and Quinacridone Gold, this specialty color is hard to replicate. It will granulate into green and reddish granules. However, it can be difficult to control in mixes.

name: Green Gold
6_mix: Equal mix of Hansa Yellow Light, New Gamboge, Pthalo Blue (GS)
Additional Information: Neutralized yellow-green, more natural then a Spring Green for spring foliage.

name: Rich Green Gold
Additional Information: This green contains no green pigment and is almost golden in its appearance. This will turn grey if mixed with red toned blues.

name: Nickel Azo Yellow
6_mix: 50% Hansa Yellow Light, 25% Quinacridone Rose, 25% Pyrrol Scarlett
Additional Information: Very similar in tone to Quinacridone Gold. This is a warm yelow-orange that will mix well with warm blues for natural greens. Mix with cool blues for pure neutrals.

name: Yellow Ochre
6_mix: 75% New Gamboge, 25% Quinacridone Rose, add very small amount of Pthalo Blue (GS) to neutralize
Additional Information: Mixed with green or green hued blues for neutralized green or with red shade blues for greys.

name: Raw Sienna
6_mix: 10% Pthalo Blue (GS), 45% Quinacridone Rose, 45% Hansa Yellow Light
3_mix: 10% Pthalo Blue (GS), 45% Quinacridone Rose, 45% Hansa Yellow Light
Additional Information: Raw sienna is one of the oldest pigments and produces a wonderful rich red brown. Mixed with a cool yellow it will produce a Yellow Ochre. Produces a wonderful rich neutral with Ultramarine blue.

name: Quinacridone Gold
Additional Information: mix

name: Quinacridone Deep Gold
transparency: Quinacridone Deep Gold is more orange than Quinacridone Gold, and more yellow than Quinacridone Burnt Orange. It’s an incredibly ruddy golden-orange, a vibrant and exciting alternative to Burnt Sienna. Quinacridones are the brightest, boldest colors modern technology can offer. Carefully selected pigments, ground to optimize their specific qualities, are blended with the finest imported Gum Arabic, put in tubes and labeled by hand. Transparency and intensity are the hallmarks of our renowned DANIEL SMITH Quinacridone colors.
Additional Information: mix

name: Quinacridone Burnt Orange
Additional Information: mix

name: Quinacridone Sienna
Additional Information: mix

name: Quinacridone Burnt Scarlet
Additional Information: mix

name: Burnt Sienna
Additional Information: mix

name: Burnt Umber
Additional Information: mix

name: Raw Umber
Additional Information: mix

name: Sepia
Additional Information: mix

name: Neutral Tint
Additional Information: mix

name: Payne’s Gray
Additional Information: mix

name: Lunar Black
Additional Information: mix

name: Chinese White
Additional Information: mix

name: Titanium White
Additional Information: mix
